title: How to Remove a Safety Band from a Bic Lighter

steps.title: With the red lever facing away from you, position a narrow but sturdy object such as a key into the flame hole of the lighter.
steps.content: With the red lever facing away from you, position a narrow but sturdy object such as a key into the flame hole of the lighter. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Use the near rim as a leverage point to push the band up in order to bend the two metal flaps holding the band in place upwards.
steps.content: Use the near rim as a leverage point to push the band up in order to bend the two metal flaps holding the band in place upwards. Occasionally, the safety band may spring off, so go slow and protect your eyes and those of others.

steps.title: With needle-nose pliers or fingers, grab the band and slowly wiggle it out like a tooth.
steps.content: With needle-nose pliers or fingers, grab the band and slowly wiggle it out like a tooth. Pulling it too hard could result in loosening the wheel. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Use the flat end of your object to gently press the metal flaps that secured the band back in place.
steps.content: Use the flat end of your object to gently press the metal flaps that secured the band back in place. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Simply take a fork and insert one of the side prongs into the top of the lighter between the 2 wheels, and simply force it up.
steps.content: Simply take a fork and insert one of the side prongs into the top of the lighter between the 2 wheels, and simply force it up. (You may have to use a thinner item, such as a small screwdriver, or a thicker paperclip; depends on the brand, again. For a Bic, a fork should work pretty well.) This forces the safety out from the prongs which hold it in -- although it should be mentioned, for the sake of safety, that sometimes it pops out fully and can hit you in the eye. (Use safety glasses, I guess?) [5] X Research source

steps.title: From there you can simply use needle-nose pliers or fingers as above to remove it fully.
steps.content: From there you can simply use needle-nose pliers or fingers as above to remove it fully. This often saves you from having to re-adjust the prongs, which can often nick your thumb, even after they've been flattened. If the prongs actually came undone, just push them back in with a hard flat object, such as the butt end of the screwdriver. You can even just press them against the edge of the table.

steps.title: Get a pocket knife out, and bring it in from the side, under the band but above the wheel.
steps.content: Get a pocket knife out, and bring it in from the side, under the band but above the wheel. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Pry up, and watch out:
steps.content: Pry up, and watch out: the band usually flies right off. Pointing the lighter downwards is a very good idea. Usually this method leaves the prongs intact; you won't have to bend them back down if this is done properly. Might take a try or two, but this should keep you honest enough of a cool guy/girl. [7] X Research source
